\gn ·Å∂·Äù·Ä∫ ·Åµ·Ä±·ÇÉ·Çà ·Äï·Äµ·Åº·Ä∫ ·Åµ·Ä∞·Çà ·Åº·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Çá ·ÇÅ·Äù·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Åµ·Ä∞·Åº·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Åã
\notes
\dt 01/Aug/2011

\lx kU
\ph ku
\hm 2
\ps n.
\ge perfume
\de perfume derived from a civet
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶ó‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶ß ‡¶¶‡ßç‡ß∞‡ß±‡ßü
\gr ‡¶∏‡ßÅ‡¶ó‡¶ø‡¶®‡¶ß ‡¶¶‡ßç‡ß∞‡ß±‡ßü
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B116
\xe nM cU nM x; nM fE[q nM nE[q x; nMvE[q mokqN; hoM kU hoM cnq hoM c;mI hoM mIr]
tiNq fj hoM ci s;mI mkq bnq kupq mkq suM a
\xn nam chu nam kha nam phvng nam nvng kha nam thvng mok nya
hom ku hom chan hom cha mi hom mi rav ten phai hom chi sa mi
mak ban kup mak sum  
\xr 'milk, 'kha' water, honey, 'kha' tea, curd, various fragrant flowers,
good-smelling torches, fragrant candles, fragrant chi incense, sweet
fruit, tarty fruit'
\xv
\notes In Terwiel and Ranoo's  translation, the word <ku>, 'perfume
derived from a civet' is subsumed in the phrase 'various fragrant
flowers', the translation of <mokya hom ku hom chan hom chami
hom'. A better translation might be 'fragrant flowers, fragrant civet
perfume, strong fragrance and 'chami' fragrance'.

\dt 01/Aug/2011

\lx kkq
\ph kak
\hm 1
\ps n.
\ge throne
\de throne 
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv ‡¶ø‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶∏‡¶®
\gr ‡¶ø‡¶∏‡¶Ç‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶∏‡¶®
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 2v5
\xe riu[q x[q kkq /
\xn rvng khang kak
\xr 'Bright at the side of the throne.'
\xv ‡¶∏‡¶ø‡¶Ç‡¶π‡¶æ‡¶∏‡¶®‡ß∞ ‡¶â‡¶ú‡ßç‡¶ú‡ßç‡¶¨‡¶≤ ‡¶´‡¶æ‡¶≤ ‡•§
\notes Nabin Shaym suggested that the word kak might mean 'throne'.
Chaichuen Khamdaengyodtai observed that in Thai Mau <khaak>
means a 'stand', which could have been extended to mean a throne.

\dt 07/Aug/2011

\lx knq
\ph kan
\hm 4
\ps n.
\ge kneeling
\de kneeling
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 31v-12
\dn Aa vU k; rI yU Akq
\dr a thu ka ri ju ak
\dv ‡¶Ü‡¶Å‡¶†‡ßÅ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶¢‡¶ø‡¶º ‡¶Ø‡ßá‡¶æ‡ß±‡¶æ‡¶ï
\gr ‡¶Ü‡¶Å‡¶†‡ßÅ ‡¶ï‡¶æ‡¶¢‡¶ø‡¶º ‡¶Ø‡ßá‡¶æ‡ß±‡¶æ‡¶ï
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes This was originally translated as 'crawling' which would correspond
to Shan kaan: However Bibek Borgohain pointed out that a thu ka ri
ju a means 'kneeling' rather than 'crawling' The meaning of /a thu ka
ri ju ak/ is t'o move by keeling', which in one word is 'crawling.'

\dt 29/Jul/2011

\lx kinq x;
\ph kin kha
\ps n
\ge small.medicine.plant
\de small medicinal plant
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 39r-5
\dn eha rU rU mENq
\dr ho ru ru mvi
\dv ‡¶∏‡ß∞‡ßÅ ‡ß∞‡ßÅ‡¶Æ‡ßà‡¶ï
\gr ‡¶∏‡ß∞‡ßÅ ‡ß∞‡ßÅ‡¶Æ‡ßà‡¶ï
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes In Shan the word ken mav refers to the part that joins a leaf to the
stem, so kin kha might refer to the joining of a branch to the tree.
This would accord with the Assamese word horu that is used here.
According to Junaram Sangbun Phukan, there is a plant/shrub
named /ho ru ru moi/

\xr 'To one person (he said), You come! I will give you the name Sing
Chvn Phai for you to sit as ruler the country of the tip of the wind to
enjoy together as a pair.'

\lx xa
\ph kha
\hm 13
\ps v.
\ge entrust
\de entrust, to
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 56v-3
\dn eKa sI borq
\dr go si bor
\dv ‡¶ó‡¶ö‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ß∞
\gr ‡¶ó‡¶ö‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ß∞
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes In Assamese gosibor means to entrust someone with something with the expectation it will be returned. A cognate term gota means 'to entrust', but without the expectation of its return, such as when giving a girl in marriage. In Dehong /xaa3/ means 'to give a daughter in marriage'.

\xe kMQ si[q k]w emoa ko[q vE[q ninq /
\xn kam sing kau mo kong thvng nin
\xr 'The echo of my words will reach the ground.'
\xv
\gn
\se xoM
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·Åµ·ÇÇ·Å¢·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏
\rf Nemi Mang; ; 6v3
\xe nj [inq[q mE[q ex] si[q topq xoM cw /
\xn nai ngin nang mvng khe sing top khom chau 
\xr 'And hearing this, the lady of the country replied in agreeable voice
to the words of the prince.'
\xv
\gn ·Äú·ÇÜ·Çà ·ÄÑ·Ä≠·Åº·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Åº·Å¢·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Äô·Ä≠·Ä∞·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Å∂·Ä±·Ä∏ ·Äû·Äµ·ÄÑ·Ä∫ ·Äê·ÄΩ·Äï·Ä∫·Çá ·Åµ·ÇÇ·Å¢·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Å∏·Äù·Ä∫·Çà ·Åã
\notes
\dt 28/Jul/2011

\lx xM
\ph kham
\hm 10
\ps v.
\sn 1
\ge pass.over
\de pass over, to; cross, to
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B22
\xe f] s[q hia n[q nj cM xupq mEw bnq xM lpq foMN; a
\xn phav sang hit nang nai cham khup mv ban kham lap phom nya
\xr 'Whoever finds himself in these circumstances should kneel down in
the evening time after sunset.'
\xv
\xe
\sn 2
\ge cross.river
\de cross a river by a boat
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 42r-20
\dn en]w dI ya borq
\dr nau di ja bor
\dv ‡¶®‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶¶‡¶ø ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶¨‡ß∞
\gr ‡¶®‡¶æ‡¶ì‡¶¶‡¶ø ‡¶Ø‡¶æ‡¶¨‡ß∞
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes For the phrase <kham lap phom nya>, Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:78)
note that they have no parallel for this expression in any other Tai
language. The phrase was read by Nabin Shyam as 'having crossed
the horizon'. Shan phom is given as 'distance which the eye can see'
(considered a yuzana in length).

\xr 'Because of his past life's wholesome acts, the diamond star

\dt 15/Jun/2011

\lx xM mE[q
\ph kham mvng
\ps n.
\ge kham.mvng
\de the second of the cycles in the Ahom time-reckoning system; an
astronomical phenomenon, probably Rahu (Terwiel and Ranoo
1992:146)
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4
\xe fa c[q pRu[q knq lkq nI xM mE[q pI pnq pI knq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham
nin to tav
\xr 'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the
cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down
to the earth underneath.'
\xv
\notes
\dt 07/Aug/2011

\lx xM rotq fa
\ph kham rot pha
\ps pn.
\ge PN
\de used to refer to the king
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 2r2
\xe xM rotq fa pitq mEnq bw mj c ... /
\xn kham rot pha pit mvn bau mai chau
\xr 'The golden one who reached the sky abandoned himself without
worry.'
\xv
\notes It is not clear whether <Kham rot pha> is the name of the king or a
form of words used to refer to the king. In this context it refers to
the father of the hero of Ma Likha Lit.

\gn ·Åæ·Å¢·Äê·Ä∫·Çà·Äê·Ä±·ÇÉ·Çà ·Äû·ÄΩ·ÄÑ·Ä∫ (·Äû·ÄΩ·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Çá) ·ÇÅ·Ä≠·Ä∞·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Å∏·ÄΩ·Äê·Ä∫·Çá ·Åµ·Ä∞·Çà ·Å∏·ÇÑ·Çà ·Åµ·Ä∞·Åº·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Å∂·ÄΩ·ÇÜ ·Å∏·Äô·Ä∫·Ä∏ ·Äö·Äù·Ä∫·Çâ
·Åã
\notes In the example for 'desire', the word khoi occurs as part of a proper
name Ngvk Khong Khoi. The word khong is probably the same as
the name of the river Mekhong, so the whole names means the
'crocodile that desires the river'

\lx [I

\hm 1
\ps n.

\de second son

\dn eA] tkq koj N eha ru tokq
\dr e tak koi ho ru tok
\dv ‡¶è‡¶ü‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶ï‡ßà ‡¶∏‡ß∞‡ßÅ‡¶ü‡ßá‡¶æ‡¶ï
\gr ‡¶è‡¶ü‡¶æ‡¶ï‡¶ï‡ßà ‡¶∏‡ß∞‡ßÅ‡¶ü‡ßá‡¶æ‡¶ï
\gv
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B133
\xe hiaq Anq Aj xunq nEnq [I xunq bnq a
\xn hit an ai khun nvn ngi khun ban
\xr 'make an image of the eldest lord moon, the second eldest lord sun'
\xv
\gn
\notes The phrase etak koi horutak means 'the smaller by one' and refers
to the second son. This was misread by G.C. Baruah and Deodhai
and Phukan as etaik koi horutak, meaning 'youngest son'

\xe nj [inq n[q mE[q ba k; nj /
\xn nai ngin nang mvng ba ka nai
\xr 'After hearing the princess, he said like this.'

compound meaning 'hear'

\notes Probably Assamese modh. Nabin Shyam suggested that this meant 'Buddhist holy recitals'. The word mOgOr is Hindi word for 'crocodile'. Chaichuen suggested that nam su la should mean 'alcohol' from Pali-Sanskrit sura 'intoxicating liquor'

\lx nE[q

\hm 1
\ps v.

\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 24r-10
\dn es] A; dI borq
\dr se a di bor
\dv --- ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ß∞

\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B116
\xe nM cU nM x; nM fE[q nM nE[q x; nMvE[q ...
\xn nam chu nam kha nam phvng nam nvng kha nam thvng ...
\xr 'milk, 'kha' water, honey, galangale tea, curd ...'

galangale' is translated as 'galangale tea'. In Terwiel and Ranoo
(1992) it was given as 'kha tea'.

Dictionary, its value is 100 ticals, about 3.3 lbs.

\dr
\dv

choi

\lx et]
\ph te
\hm 5
\ps adj., part.
\sn 1
\ge true
\de true 
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·Äê·ÇÑ·Çâ
\rf Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 21r3
\xe s[q ma lkq fitq et] nj cM m] n[q ya na nU cU /
\xn sang ma lak phit te nai cham mav nang ya na nu chu
\xr 'Even if you make mistake do not show it on your face.'
\xv
\gn
\sn 2
\ge TRUE
\de particle
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·Äê·ÇÑ·Çâ
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r5
\xe nnq vE[q ninq citq rnq et] na /
\xn nan thvng nin chit ran te na
\xr 'Truly the noise (of my voice) will reach the seven layers of ground.'
\xv
\gn
\notes The phrase <te na> is conventionalised as an combination of two
particles. <te> is the word 'true' 
\notes The phrase <phit te nai> in the example is literally 'a true mistake, a
real mistake'

\dt 26/Aug/2011

\lx tj
\ph tai
\hm 5
\ps n.
\ge side
\de side
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·Äê·Å¢·ÇÜ·Çà
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r3
\xe tj kw emoa tkq m; kU si[q cM l] cw xja kw ep] mE[q pkq /
\xn tai kau mo tak ma ku sing cham lau chau khai pha kau pe mvng pak
\xr 'I the learned one will come and speak to my great king who is the
support for a hundred countries.'
\xv
\gn
\notes The word tai appears to mean 'side', but is not translated in the
English free translation, it means literally 'my voice, which is the side
of the learned one, is effective.'

\hm 6

\dt 26/Aug/2011

\lx tj
\ph tai
\hm 7
\ps v.
\ge walk.with.torch
\de walk with a torch, to
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 5r-23
\dn yurq ela gj fU rI borq
\dr jur loi phu ri bor
\dv ‡¶ú‡¶æ‡ß∞‡ßç ‡¶≤‡ßà ‡¶´‡ßÅ‡ß∞‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ß∞
\gr ‡¶ú‡¶æ‡ß∞‡ßç ‡¶≤‡ßà ‡¶´‡ßÅ‡ß∞‡¶ø‡¶¨‡ß∞
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes Junaram Phuakn said that /jur lo gai phu ri bor/ might also be said as
/ba jur lo gai phu ri bor/ where /ba/ means 'air' so it would mean 'to
walk in an airy atmosphere' (air touching the body while walking
leisurely).

\dt 31/Aug/2011

\lx tokq
\ph tok
\hm 1
\ps n.
\ge measure.of.weight
\de a measure of weight
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B91
\xe cw sI lj ela c[q [Enq 2 tokq a
\xn chau chi lai ko chang ngvn song tok
\xr 'For the scribes a weight of 2 toks of silver.'
\xv
\notes Terwiel and Ranoo (1992:150) note "a measure of weight;
according to Nabin Shyam, the Tai Aiton and Tai Phakey at present
consider the tok to weigh approximately one kilogram, but in these
texts the tok is used for amounts of gold we assume it to be a much
smaller weight.'

\de with

\gr

\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r7

\xr 'See a group of elephants, surrounding the country of the Lord, king

\xv

arguments in Ahom. The example here, <han tang phung chang>
'see with group elephant' is translated into English as simply 'See a
group of elephants'

\lx t[q rnq
\ph tang ran
\ps n.
\ge ?
\de ?
\so Loti Amra; (Prem Phukon); 8v-3
\dn bI D; dI A; pa totq
\dr bindha dia patot
\dv ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßç‡¶ß‡¶æ ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡ßü‡¶æ ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶§‡¶§
\gr ‡¶¨‡¶ø‡¶®‡ßç‡¶ß‡¶æ ‡¶¶‡¶ø‡ßü‡¶æ ‡¶™‡¶æ‡¶§‡¶§
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes Junaram Phukan said another meaning of /pat/ is 'akon' seat and  /bi
dhan/ means 'custom'. So the whole might mean 'the act of taking a
seat in religious prayer by a person, throne (by king), or placing
things on a plate according to custom'. In Shan /taang/ means 'place
upon'.

\lx pa
\ph pa
\hm 11
\ps part.
\ge PROH
\de prohibitive marker, do not
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv
\rf Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 13v5
\xe xM s[q m] xunq y; pa hj /
\xn kham sang mav khun ya pa hai
\xr '"Any way, you prince, do not cry."' 
\xv
\gn
\notes This word is a shortened form of the word <pai> 'not yet, do not'. A
similar form is found in spoken Tai Aiton

\lx pI pnq
\ph pi pan
\ps n.
\ge Pi.Pan
\de the 'revolving year', the third of the cycles in an Ahom time
reckoning system [cf Cush 408] (Terwiel and Ranoo 1992:154)
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4
\xe fa c[q pRu[q knq lkq nI xM mE[q pI pnq pI knq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham
nin to tav
\xr 'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the
cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down
to the earth underneath.'
\xv
\notes
\dt 17/Aug/2011

\lx pI hnq
\ph pi han
\ps n.
\ge Pi.Han
\de the 'completed year', the fourth and last of the cycles in an Ahom
time reckoning system (Terwiel and Ranoo 1992:154)
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4
\xe fa c[q pRu[q knq lkq nI xM mE[q pI pnq pI knq cM bunq cM ninq eta t] a
\xn pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham
nin to tav
\xr 'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the
cycle called Pan, the cycle called Han, from the space above down
to the earth underneath.'
\xv
\gn
\notes This may be <pi kan>

realised as <pu> in Ahom

is being invited to return to the country, so no sense of movement
away is implied.

\xr 'The red golden one, feeling sad, spoke the words saying, Move, and

which is clearly an error

\dt 11/Aug/2011

\lx p[q
\ph pang
\hm 9
\ps n.
\ge satin
\de satin, this meaning is conjectural according to Terwiel and Ranoo
(1992:154)
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B126
\xe huM p[q huM bnq xM 2 fEnq xpq fa 2 ...
\xn hum pang hum ban kham song phvn khap pha song ...
\xr 'satin, a piece of cloth with gold silk threads inserted, two pieces of
violet cloth ...'
\xv
\notes Terwiel and Ranoo suggest that this might be a Chinese loanword.
Given the context of the example, it should relate to cloth.

\xe em] pI lkq nI xM mE[q nj cM kU pI m; kU co[q a
\xn me pi lak ni kham mvng nai cham ku pi ma ku chong
\xr 'The major time-reckoning systems, Lakni and Kham Mvng, come
and revolve every year'
\xv

\so

\dr
\dv

\xn sen khun sung sui chang kvn ma ku nvn

\xr 'After that, it reached the fifth month.'
\xv

\dt 03/Aug/2011

\lx m; pkq
\ph ma pak
\ps n.
\ge pumpkin
\de pumpkin
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B185
\xe A] m;pkq A] nM cU hU A] nM x; A] nM fE[q A] nMvE[q el] citq xi[q citq
xi[q a
\xn av ma pak av nam chu hu av nam kha av nam phvng av nam thvng
le chit khing chit khing
\xr  'pumpkins, cow's milk, 'kha' water, honey and curd; in two sets
each set having seven things'
\xv
\notes Terwiel and Ranoo note that 'pumpikin' in Shan is <mak pak> with
reference to Cushing p469. This example begins with the words <au
ma> which might mean 'bring' (literally 'take come'). Alternatively
the reading of <ma pak> 'suggests that <ma> is a short form of the
word <mak> 'fruit'. This form is found in the Tai languages still
spoken in Assam, like Phake and Aiton.
\dt 03/Aug/2011

\notes Tileswar Mohan says /ko boj ka pur/ means 'shield like dress worn by soldier'.

'dress worn by actors in drama'

\so Loti Amra; (Prem Phukon); 16v-1
\dn kpq eD] kI Akq
\dr kap dhekia-k

\xe voj s[q xjfa em] poj m; /
\xn thoi sang khai pha me poi ma

\gn ·Äë·ÄΩ·ÇÜ·Çà (·Äû·Å¢·ÄÑ·Ä∫·Çá) ·Å∂·ÇÜ·Çá·Åæ·ÇÉ·Çâ ·Äô·ÇÑ·Çà ·Äï·ÄΩ·ÇÜ·Ä∏ ·Äô·ÇÉ·Ä∏ ·Åã

combination with 'khom/khwam'. In the example from Nemi Mang;
; 7r7, it is not translated but conveys the fact that these are the
words of the mother.

\lx sj
\ph sai
\hm 5
\ps n.
\ge rainbow
\de rainbow, the appearance of a rainbow in the east
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 11r-5
\dn pu bot er] nu Au lu Akq
\dr pu bot re nu u lu ak
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B138
\xe n]w sjru[q n]w kiNqcw n]w rEnq k[q n]w kunq a
\xn nau sai rung nau ken chau nau rvn kang nau kun
\xr 'the Rainbow Star(s), the Lord Star(s), the Middle House Stars, the
Basket Stars'
\xv
\notes It appears that the compound <sai rung>, literally 'line bright' is the
Ahom word for 'rainbow'

\hm 9
\ps n.
\ge Morning.Star
\de name of a star or planet, literally 'Morning Star'
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B41
\xe poj spq Aokq n]w lu[q kM bnqAokq mEw Aipqsj cM ba n]w sj a
\xn poi sang ok nau lung kam ban ok mv ip sai cham ba nau sai
\xr 'If a large star appears in the east during the morning, this is called
the Morning Star'
\xv
\notes
\dt 22/Aug/2011

\lx sj ru[q
\ph sai rung
\ps n.
\ge rainbow
\de rainbow, also the name of a constellation, 'Rainbow Stars'
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B138
\xe n]w sjru[q n]w kiNqcw n]w rEnq k[q n]w kunq a
\xn nau sai rung nau ken chau nau rvn kang nau kun
\xr 'the Rainbow Star(s), the Lord Star(s), the Middle House Stars, the
Basket Stars'
\xv
\notes
\dt 22/Aug/2011

\lx siw
\ph siu
\hm 1
\ps n.
\ge tree.type
\de tree, type of
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 5v7
\xe A] t[q l] k[q vEnq Notq siw /
\xn au tang lav kang thvn nyot siu
\xr 'Take liquor made of the new leaves of the forest siu tree.'
\xv
\notes Chaichuen Khamdaengyodtai confirmed that the new leaves of the
siu are used in food preparation. Maybe this line refers to the herbs
put into the laopani or Ahom liquor.

\xn yu le yu mav pa ya tang lai khav vi
\xr 'You, stay with all your aunts and grandmothers.'

\gn
\notes The form in the Bar Amra is literally 'great-grandmother', but this
word is well known in the meaning 'grandmother'

\xr 'slaughtering people in great numbers'

\ge bush
\de bush
\so
\dn

\dv
\gr

\xn khau chang nai khvng kvng kan cham ku nyum khv
\xr 'They got to do suitable things at every bush and creeper.'
\xv
\notes In the example, the phrase <nyum nya>, literally 'a clump of grass'
is translated as 'in great numbers'

\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A4

\xn pha chang prung kan lakni kham mvng pi pan pi kan cham bun cham

\xr 'the Gods then assigned the sixty-year cycle, Kham Mu'ng, the

\xv
\gn
\notes In the example, the word <lak ni> is literally 'the peg of year'. This
refers to the custom of marking the days and years by shifting a peg
into a different hole each day, on a board with sixty squares, each
containing a hole.

\dt 01/Aug/2011

\lx linq
\ph lin
\hm 11
\ps v.
\ge roll.up
\de roll up, to
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 6v1
\xe miNq n; c; n[q linq k[q /
\xn men na cha nang lin kang
\xr 'With the bad faced Hill Tribals who roll up their chins.'
\xv
\notes The reading of <lin> as 'roll up' in the example is uncertain. We
originally read the last two words as lin kang 'tongue lose', with the
overall translation of 'the Hill Tribals who have lost their tongues',
referring to the fact that their language is not understandable. The
reading 'roll up chin', as if to screw up the chin. An alternative
reading would be lin 'stretch out'.

\hm 7
\ps v.
\ge run
\de run
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r7
\xe tj kw yU tunq linq m; ltq /
\xn tai kau yu tun lin ma lat
\xr 'I will quickly come to speak.'
\xv
\notes In the example, the phrase <tun lin>, literally 'body run' is translated
'quickly'

\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 44v-24
\dn epa yI eAa kokq
\dr po ji o kok
\dv
\gr
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\xe
\sn 2
\ge child
\de small child
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 44v-25
\dn ep] eta h nokq
\dr pe to ? nok
\dv
\gr
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes The first sense has two possible meanings in Assamese: (1) son's
daughter (po 'son' and jiek 'daughter', or (2) 'son and daughter'. The
-ek is a third person suffix in Assamese. For the second sense
Tileswar Mohan suggested that it might be  /be to nok/ 'salary'.

\dt 08/Oct/2013

\lx bj
\ph bai
\hm 2
\ps n.
\ge cane
\de cane, rattan
\so Bar Amra; (Junaram Sangbun Phukan); 15r-16
\dn eb] tokq
\dr be tok
\dv
\gr
\rf
\xe
\xn
\xr
\xv
\notes
\dt 07/Aug/2011

\lx bj
\ph bai
\hm 3
\ps v.
\sn 1
\ge keep
\de keep 
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·Äù·ÇÜ·Çâ
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 14r2
\xe Aow m; xokq likq bj t[q tU /
\xn au ma khok lik bai tang tu
\xr 'The whole body of the horse has been taken and kept in the iron
cage.'
\xv
\gn
\sn 2
\ge KEEP
\de grammaticalisation of the verb 'keep', showing that an action is past
and will have long term results.
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 8v5
\xe fI fj poj m; c[q tkq kEpq Ao] m; xunq xI x] y[q s] tM xokq likq bj
t[q tU /
\xn phi phai poi ma chang tak kvp au ma khun khi khav yang sav tam
khok lik bai tang tu
\xr 'The giants came out, and taking the horse of the prince by force,
they (the giants) put (the horse) into a metal room.'
\xv
\notes In the example the phrase sav (tam khok lik) bai is literally 'put (into
the metal pen) and keep there'

mean 'tree mushroom'. If read as /kor phul/, it would mean a kind of
root eaten with betel nut.

\lx bow hoM to[q

\notes In Ahom Lexicon, Loti Amra section, /bok hom/ meaning 'kind of
white and small fragrant garden flower' (kho ri ka jai) is mentioned.
Thus /bau/ is probably an error for /bok/.

\dn hotq krq eka rI

\xe r[q mutq ema si[q x] vukq h] xoM boj tI fI xo] t[q lj a
\xn rang mut mo sing khav thuk hav khom boi ti phi khau tang lai

\dn muNq mokq

\dt 07/Aug/2011

\lx hU
\ph hu
\hm 4
\ps v.
\ge recite
\de recite, to
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 4v1
\xe k]w ema mE[q eka c[q tkq hU xj m] pU cEw /
\xn kau mo mvng ko chang tak hu khai mav pu chv
\xr 'I, the learned one of the country recite and tell the lineage of you,
ancestors.'
\xv
\notes This word is apparently an irregular spelling of <ho> 'preach,
recite>. Chaichuen Khamdaengyodtai pointed out that <hu khai>
usually means 'cattle and buffaloes' but we would expect a verb
after <chang tak>.  In Dehong the word <ho> 'preach, recite, utter'
is <ho≤>, with a mid high vowel.
\dt 07/Aug/2011

\sn 1

\dn dI borq
\dr di bor
\dv
\gr
\gv ·ÇÅ·ÇÇ·Ä∫·Çà
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; A13
\xe vukq hiaq r[q fa niuw rU riunq ecoa lopq Anq l[q 1 h] hiaq foa fEkq mu[q
koj a
\xn thuk hit rang pha nv ru rvn cho lop an lang lvng hav hit pha phvk
mung koi 
\xr 'let a figure of the sky above (our) heads be set up in a small ritual
building and cover it with white cloth'
\xv
\gn
\sn 2
\notes GIVE
\de grammaticalisation of the verb 'give' meaning 'let', 'allow', 'make
someone do something'
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\gv ·ÇÅ·ÇÇ·Ä∫·Çà
\rf Ma Likha Lit; (Medini Mohan); 1v1
\xe lukq cw h] pj rikq t[q ema s[q fa m; po[q /
\xn luk chau hav pai rik tang mo sang pha ma pong
\xr 'When he woke in the morning, he made someone go and call the
Mo Sang Pha to come and take care of this.'
\xv
\gn
\dt 23/Jul/2011

\xv

\notes In Terwiel and Ranoo's analysis the calendrical cycle called <Pi
Han> is literally 'year complete'. However, since <han> also means
'revolve', it may be 'revolving year', a meaning also suggested for
<Pi Pan>.

\lx Aipq

\hm 4
\ps v.
\ge near
\de to be near [Cush 689]
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Tai Ahoms and the Stars; ; B41
\xe poj spq Aokq n]w lu[q kM bnqAokq mEw Aipqsj cM ba n]w sj a
\xn poi sang ok nau lung kam ban ok mv ip sai cham ba nau sai
\xr 'If a large star appears in the east during the morning, this is called
the Morning Star'
\xv
\notes In the example the phrase <ip sai> is literally 'near the morning'

\lx @
\ph ru lai
\ps n.
\ge opening.word
\de a marker of Ahom orthography showing the beginning of a section
of text. It is used very frequently in some texts and much less often
in others.
\so
\dn
\dr
\dv
\gr
\rf Ming Mvng; (Tileswar Mohan); 1r1
\xe @ fo[q lu[q to[q fo[q mokq /
\xn rulai phong lung tong phong mok
\xr 'During this great time, it is the time of the (meghela) flower.'
\xv
